p: The different functions between IFN-λs and type I IFNs can be explained by the different STAT complex they activated. When engaged with their receptor complexes, both IFN-λs and type I IFNs activate JAK-family kinases, which phosphorylate STAT1 and STAT2. The phosphorylated STAT1 and STAT2 dimerize and translocate to the nucleus where they associate with IRF9 to form IFN-stimulated gene factor 3 (ISGF3), bind to IFN-stimulated response elements (ISREs) and induces the expression of antiviral ISGs. However, engagement of type I IFNs with their receptor can also activate the STAT1 homodimer which binds to gamma-activated sequence (GAS) and induces the expression of pro-inflammatory cytokines and chemokines (Ivashkiv and Donlin, 2014). Thus, type I IFNs have the potential of inducing inflammation in addition to antiviral function, while IFN-λs promote the production of antiviral ISGs without the function of inducing inflammation (Fig. 2).
